block.para: What exactly do we mean by the angle between two nonzero vectors? – Consider the image below

If \Vect{x} and \Vect{y} are not parallel, the angle \theta from \Vect{x} to \Vect{y} is the shorter of the two possible arcs from \Vect{x} to \Vect{y}; the angle \theta in the image above. It is always a number between 0 and \pi.

li.para: \theta = 0 if the vectors have the same directions.
\theta = \pi if the vectors have opposite directions.

block.para: Remarkable is that \cos \theta is readily computable using the dot product:
So the cos of the angle between the vectors is their dot product divided by their lengths.
